lens.book_chapters: Cold Start Theory Framework + Chapters 4-10: Tiny Speck/Slack, Anti-Network Effects, The Atomic Network, The Hard Side, Solve a Hard Problem, The Killer Product, Magic Moments, Tipping Point, Escape Velocity, Hitting the Ceiling, The Moat

reinforcements.similarity: Both elements center on the Stays Manager as the primary guest engagement surface. guest-works-003 prescribes designing the Stays Manager as a System 1 weekly dashboard with minimal cognitive load. rb-ui-0933-002 (Engagement Ladder Progress Strip) extends this by adding a progressive value layer on top of the dashboard -- the same surface, but now with a tier system that reveals new capabilities over tenure.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence (guest-works-003): The Stays Manager is the most-visited page (13+ times per lease), and it must operate at System 1 speed. Reverse-benchmark evidence (PadSplit analysis): PadSplit's dashboard is a billing portal with zero progressive value -- month 1 = month 12. Chen's Engagement Effect (Ch. 3) requires 'introducing people to new use cases' over time. Combined: the Stays Manager is the right surface (validated by DS) and the engagement ladder is the right mechanism (validated by RB). Together they form the engagement engine that PadSplit structurally cannot build.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: This is a strong cross-process reinforcement. The design-stack pipeline identified the Stays Manager as foundational through direct user analysis (Nneka, Brad, weekly visit patterns). The reverse-benchmark pipeline independently identified progressive engagement as the critical missing ingredient through competitor analysis (PadSplit's flatline experience). Finding the same surface from inside-out (user needs) and outside-in (competitor gaps) is the strongest possible validation signal. This is now the 8th independent process to identify the Stays Manager as foundational architecture.

reinforcements.similarity: Both elements address micro-review accumulation in the Stays Manager. rb-ui-101 (from the Booking.com/Hooked run) created the one-tap micro-review mechanism -- the data capture layer. rb-ui-0933-003 (Shared Housing Passport) creates the aggregation and portability layer -- the data output. Together they form a complete system: micro-reviews feed the Passport, and the Passport gives micro-reviews purpose beyond any single lease.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Booking.com/Hooked run evidence: Eyal's Hook Model shows that single post-checkout reviews are structurally incapable of habit formation for 3+ month leases. The solution is one-tap micro-reviews at each weekly stay cycle (13+ per lease). PadSplit/Cold Start run evidence: Chen's Moat chapter shows that network effects create defensibility through switching costs. A portable reputation built from accumulated micro-reviews creates genuine switching costs -- leave Split Lease and lose months of verified trust. Combined: the Hook Model provides the input mechanism (weekly micro-reviews) and the Cold Start Theory provides the output mechanism (portable reputation as moat).
reinforcements.confidence_boost: Two different reverse-benchmark runs, analyzing two different competitors through two different book frameworks, independently converged on the same system: weekly micro-reviews (Booking.com/Hooked) that accumulate into portable reputation (PadSplit/Cold Start). This cross-run convergence within the RB pipeline is a secondary reinforcement signal on top of the DS/RB cross-process signal from the Stays Manager.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address trust bridging at critical transitions. works-004 (Bridge Human Trust to Digital Trust Through Continuity Priming) prescribes transferring agent trust to the platform through visual and verbal continuity. rb-ui-0933-001 (House Welcome Card) extends this from the agent-to-platform handoff to the platform-to-house handoff: transferring platform trust to the social environment through co-tenant profiles and schedule previews.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence: Hosts trust Bryant, not the platform. The platform must inherit trust from the human relationship. Reverse-benchmark evidence: PadSplit members walk into houses with zero social context. The house must inherit trust from the platform relationship. Combined: trust bridging is a fractal pattern that applies at every transition -- agent-to-platform (DS), platform-to-house (RB), and within the house across turnovers (RB). The principle is identical; the application contexts expand.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: The trust-bridging pattern appearing in both DS and RB processes confirms it is not a single-context phenomenon but a structural principle of the Split Lease journey. DS found it at the host-side evaluation-to-onboarding transition. RB found it at the guest-side acceptance-to-move-in transition. This suggests trust bridging should be a design system pattern applied at every major transition, not just the specific ones identified in each run.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the emotional arc over a 13-week lease. guest-feels-001 prescribes a shifting emotional tone in the Stays Manager: warm guidance early, efficient data mid-lease, grateful acknowledgment at close. rb-ui-0933-006 (House Continuity Welcome Note) addresses the emotional arc at the house level: the Anchor's welcome note sets the warm tone at move-in, and the note evolves with each new co-tenant, maintaining emotional continuity across turnovers.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence: The Stays Manager must shift its emotional register across 13 weeks because a design that stays warm and instructional on Week 10 feels patronizing. Reverse-benchmark evidence: PadSplit's houses have no emotional arc -- every move-in is equally cold. The House Anchor's welcome note provides the emotional warm start that makes the first week feel like joining a home rather than checking into a facility. Combined: the Stays Manager handles the digital emotional arc, and the Welcome Note handles the social emotional arc. Together they create a complete emotional experience from the first day.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: Moderate. The DS element is strongly validated through direct user analysis. The RB element is validated through competitor gap analysis but lacks direct transcript evidence for the specific welcome note mechanism. The convergence on emotional arcs over time is meaningful, but the Welcome Note's specific form factor needs DS validation.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the psychological shift from passive participant to active contributor. works-005 (Engineer the Host-as-Advisor Moment) prescribes creating moments where hosts contribute expertise rather than just data, which activates commitment through consistency pressure. rb-ui-0933-004 (House Anchor Badge and Influence Panel) extends this to guests: Anchors who contribute community labor (welcome notes, co-tenant reviews, referrals) experience the same advisor-to-commitment shift.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence: Andreas shifted from questioning ('Is there a broker fee?') to advising ('I think just a bed, things for the kitchen') at 5:12 of his call, marking the commitment moment. Reverse-benchmark evidence: Chen (Ch. 7) identifies the hard side as users who 'do more work and contribute more to the network.' The House Anchor role formalizes the advisor shift: guests who invest community labor become committed to the house network through the same consistency mechanism that commits hosts. Combined: the advisor-to-commitment pattern operates across both sides of the marketplace.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: Moderate. The DS element has direct transcript evidence (Andreas). The RB element has theoretical support from Chen but no direct transcript evidence for the specific Anchor role. The cross-process convergence on the advisor-commitment mechanism is sound theory, but the Anchor role needs behavioral validation.

extensions.gap_filled: The Shared Housing Passport fills the post-stay/retention gap in the guest journey. No existing library element addresses portable reputation across leases. The library has micro-review input (rb-ui-101 through 104) and Stays Manager design (guest-works-003), but the aggregation into a portable, cross-lease reputation profile is entirely new.
extensions.confidence_note: Moderate confidence. The Passport concept is well-supported by Chen's Moat theory (switching costs through accumulated value) and partially validated by transcripts (hosts demand reputation signals: 'I do very odd interviews,' 'what are they there for?'). However, the specific mechanism -- a portable trust score built from micro-reviews -- has no direct user feedback. The closest validation is the Booking.com/Hooked run's micro-review system, which provides the data input but not the aggregation output.
extensions.needs_design_stack_validation: Yes. A future design-stack run should specifically analyze guest calls for evidence of reputation anxiety ('what if my next host doesn't know I was a good tenant?') and host calls for evidence of reputation demand ('I want to see their track record, not just a background check'). The Sherene and Tammy calls partially cover this but were not analyzed through the specific lens of cumulative portable reputation.

extensions.gap_filled: The House Personality Search Card fills the discovery/search gap in the guest journey. No existing library element surfaces social composition during search. The library has listing evaluation elements (guest-looks-003, 004) that address room presentation, but the house personality layer is entirely new.
extensions.confidence_note: Moderate confidence with caveats. The concept is strongly supported by Chen's Atomic Network theory (composition matters more than count) and validated by three transcripts (Susan, Valerie/Frederick, Vince all asking about who else is there). However, the specific mechanism -- auto-generated house personality summaries -- requires sufficient data (micro-reviews, co-tenant profiles) that may not exist during early platform growth. The chicken-and-egg problem is significant.
extensions.needs_design_stack_validation: Yes. A future design-stack run focused on the guest search phase should analyze how guests currently discover and evaluate listings, specifically looking for the moment they ask 'who else is there?' This was partially covered in the Susan and Frederick/Valerie calls but deserves dedicated analysis. The search UX is also a good candidate for a reverse-benchmark run against Roomi or SpareRoom, which have rudimentary social features.

extensions.gap_filled: The Community Referral Invitation Card fills the retention/acquisition gap. No existing library element addresses house-level referrals. The library's referral-related elements (if any) are generic. This element specifically ties referrals to a house network, creating Chen's Acquisition Effect at the atomic level.
extensions.confidence_note: Moderate confidence. Steve Zhang's referral of Joyce ('I was telling Joyce about split Lee's') is the strongest transcript evidence -- it was a social referral (friend-to-friend, about a specific lifestyle fit) not an economic one (link for bonus). Chen's Acquisition Effect theory supports the mechanism. However, the specific form factor (house-specific invitation with preview) is novel and untested.
extensions.needs_design_stack_validation: Yes, but lower priority than the Passport and Search Card. The referral mechanism is an extension of the engagement system, not a standalone feature. Validate the engagement ladder and Anchor system first; the referral card flows naturally from those.

cross_process_insights.insight: The Stays Manager convergence signal is now at 8+ independent processes. This PadSplit/Cold Start run adds the engagement ladder dimension: the Stays Manager is not just a weekly dashboard (DS) with micro-reviews (RB/Booking.com) but also the progressive engagement engine that creates the Escape Velocity forces PadSplit completely lacks. The Stays Manager has been identified as foundational by: Kahneman (System 1 dashboard), Eyal/Hooked (micro-review habit loop), Christensen/Innovator's Dilemma (sustaining innovation), Lean UX/Sonder (hypothesis-driven engagement), Cialdini (reciprocity in reviews), Norman (affordances/signifiers), Chen/Cold Start (engagement ladder and atomic network activation), and Krug (don't make me think). No other architectural element in the library has this convergence depth.
cross_process_insights.implication: The Stays Manager is the single most validated architectural decision in the design stack. Product investment should be concentrated here first. The engagement ladder (rb-ui-0933-002) should be built on top of the existing Stays Manager dashboard design (guest-works-003), incorporating the micro-review mechanism (rb-ui-101) and the emotional arc (guest-feels-001). This is not 4 separate features -- it is one integrated surface with layered capabilities.

cross_process_insights.insight: Trust bridging is a fractal pattern that operates at every scale of the platform. Design-stack discovered it at the agent-to-platform handoff (works-004). This reverse-benchmark run discovered it at the platform-to-house handoff (rb-ui-0933-001) and at the turnover continuity level (rb-ui-0933-006). The same principle -- bridge trust from a known context to an unknown context through visual, verbal, and social continuity -- applies from the macro (will I trust this platform?) to the micro (will I trust this housemate?). This suggests trust bridging should become a design system primitive, not a one-off pattern.
cross_process_insights.implication: The design system should include 'Trust Bridge' as a reusable component pattern: when a user transitions from a known context to an unknown context, the new context must lead with recognizable signals from the prior context. This applies to: agent-to-platform (show agent's name), platform-to-house (show co-tenant profiles), turnover-to-new-tenant (show Anchor's welcome note), and even within-session phase transitions (show prior step's data).

cross_process_insights.insight: The design-stack pipeline (inside-out) and the reverse-benchmark pipeline (outside-in) independently identified the same strategic axis: the transition from transactional housing to relational community. DS elements focus on making the transaction feel human (trust gates, conversational speed, depleted-user design). RB elements focus on building the community that transcends the transaction (atomic network, engagement ladder, portable reputation, house anchor). These are two halves of the same thesis: make the transaction human (DS), and make the relationship outlast the transaction (RB). Neither half alone is sufficient.
cross_process_insights.implication: The product roadmap should sequence DS elements first (they improve the existing transaction) and RB elements second (they build new capabilities). But both should be designed with awareness of the other: DS trust gates should anticipate the community features that follow, and RB community features should inherit the human-centered design language that DS establishes.

cross_process_insights.insight: The Hard Side pattern maps differently in DS vs. RB but points to the same conclusion. In DS, the host is the hard side of the marketplace (works-005: they do more work, have higher expectations, will try competitors). In RB, the House Anchor is the hard side of the house network (rb-ui-0933-004: they do community-building labor that stabilizes the atomic network). Split Lease has two hard sides that must be served simultaneously: the host (who provides inventory) and the house anchor guest (who provides community). PadSplit only serves the host-as-investor side.
cross_process_insights.implication: The product must identify and serve both hard sides. The host needs advisory moments and control (DS). The House Anchor guest needs recognition and tools (RB). When these two hard sides align -- a host who is also engaged in the community, or an Anchor guest who helps the host maintain standards -- the house network reaches maximum stability. Product features should create alignment between host and Anchor interests.

new_tokens_flagged: All 7 elements use production style guide tokens (--primary-purple: #31135D, --secondary-purple: rgb(109, 49, 194), --accent-purple: rgb(140, 104, 238), --success-color: #4B47CE, --border-color: #e5e7eb, --bg-off-white: rgb(252, 250, 255)). No non-standard colors introduced.
Fonts: All elements use Inter (UI headings, labels) and DM Sans (body text), matching the production style guide.
Border radius: All elements use --rounded-xl (12px) for cards and --rounded-pill (20px) for buttons/badges, matching production tokens.
Shadows: All elements use --shadow-sm and --shadow-md from the production guide. Purple-tinted shadows used for emphasis per style guide.

Note: tokens.json uses a different color system (warm green accent #2d5a3d, Instrument Serif, Outfit fonts) that conflicts with the production style guide. All new elements follow the production style guide, not tokens.json. This is consistent with the known token drift documented in MEMORY.md.
token_compliance.recommendation: No new tokens needed. All elements are compliant with the production style guide. The token drift between tokens.json and the production style guide should be resolved in a future cleanup -- tokens.json should be updated to match the production CSS variables documented in Style-guide.md.

discovery.notes: rb-ui-0933-005 (House Personality Search Card) serves discovery/search. discovery-003 (Multi-Local Identity) from L2 suggests additional discovery elements. DS pipeline has not yet produced guest discovery elements.

evaluation.notes: DS has strong host evaluation elements (works-001 through 006, communicates-001 through 007). RB adds guest listing evaluation through rb-ui-0933-005. Good cross-process coverage.

onboarding.notes: DS covers host onboarding (works-004, communicates-001). RB adds guest move-in onboarding (rb-ui-0933-001, rb-ui-0933-006). The pre-move-in community activation is a new dimension not previously covered.

listing_creation.notes: DS covers host listing creation thoroughly (works-003, works-006, communicates-002). No RB elements in this phase, which is expected -- listing creation is host-side and competitor gaps are guest-side.

pricing.notes: DS covers pricing (works-006, looks-003). No RB elements in this phase.

proposal_mgmt.notes: DS covers host proposal management. RB adds the Anchor's co-tenant preview capability (rb-ui-0933-004), which extends proposal management to include community input.

active_lease.notes: The densest phase in the library. DS contributes the Stays Manager design (guest-works-003, guest-feels-001, guest-feels-002, etc.). RB contributes the engagement ladder (rb-ui-0933-002), Passport (rb-ui-0933-003), Anchor system (rb-ui-0933-004), and community referral (rb-ui-0933-007). This phase benefits most from cross-process convergence. The Stays Manager is the surface; the RB elements are the progressive value layered on top.

retention.notes: DS has some host retention elements. RB adds guest retention through the Passport (switching costs), Anchor recognition (status that only exists on Split Lease), and community referrals (social bonds that retain both parties). Retention is the phase where RB elements provide the most novel coverage.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Run a guest-focused design-stack analysis through the specific lens of portable reputation and trust accumulation. Analyze Susan Bryant, Sherene, and Tammy calls (plus any additional guest calls) for evidence of reputation anxiety and trust-signal demand. Use Cialdini's Social Proof chapter as the book lens -- the Shared Housing Passport is fundamentally a social proof mechanism, and Cialdini's framework would provide the behavioral science foundation for how to present cumulative trust data.
next_run_recommendations.reason: The Shared Housing Passport (rb-ui-0933-003) is the strongest moat opportunity but currently has only moderate transcript validation. A DS run focused on reputation would either strongly reinforce the Passport concept or reveal that users don't actually care about portable reputation (in which case, the Passport should be de-prioritized). Given the strategic importance of the moat, this validation is high-priority.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Run a reverse-benchmark analysis of Roomster or SpareRoom through the lens of the engagement ladder. These platforms have rudimentary social features (member profiles, compatibility filters) that PadSplit lacks entirely. Analyzing what they tried and where they fell short would refine the engagement ladder design and identify anti-patterns to avoid. Use Nir Eyal's Hooked (investment phase chapters) as the book lens.
next_run_recommendations.reason: The engagement ladder (rb-ui-0933-002) is ranked #2 in opportunities and builds on the Stays Manager convergence. Analyzing a competitor that attempted some social features (unlike PadSplit, which has none) would provide more nuanced design guidance than analyzing pure commodity platforms.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Run a guest-focused design-stack analysis specifically on the search-to-move-in journey arc. Analyze guest calls where the searcher asks 'who else is there?' or expresses anxiety about the unknown co-tenant. Use Don Norman's 'The Design of Everyday Things' (affordances and signifiers chapters) as the lens -- the search card and house welcome card need strong signifiers that communicate social information at a glance.
next_run_recommendations.reason: The House Personality Search Card (rb-ui-0933-005) and House Welcome Card (rb-ui-0933-001) are high-impact elements that currently rely on competitor gap analysis rather than direct user evidence. A DS run focused on the pre-move-in guest journey would validate or refine these designs.
